summary: Mixed reality systems like NeuroReach VR can enhance stroke rehabilitation by providing engaging and adaptive training for reach and grasp movements.
text: NeuroReach VR is a mixed-reality system designed to train stroke patients in reach and grasp using tasks like pouring and tracing, incorporating visual, auditory, and haptic feedback. The system aims to improve selective muscle activation in the arms of stroke survivors through these interactive training methods. The training environment is gamified, featuring intuitive feedback mechanisms and motivational elements that have potential for clinical application. Demonstrations include live on-headset sessions with real-time feedback like halos, ticks, and error bars, alongside a projected dashboard displaying performance metrics.

Goal: EMG biofeedback for wrist extension to complement pouring and tracing [4]. Idea: Stream Myo sEMG into
Unity, compute %MVC, show twin bars with target bands, add haptic tick and buzz feedback. Rationale: Improves
engagement and selective activation. Outcome: Quick add-on with extra KPIs (time-in-target, ratio, co-contraction)
and demo toggle mode.

NeuroReach VR
Mixed Reality Project Proposal
Supervised by: Marwen Mokni, Christoph Bauer, Petar Lukovic
October 6, 2025
GROUP MEMBERS
Partha Sarathi
Purkayastha
Alexandre Elsig Raphael Fl¨uckiger Rakhmatillokhon
Khoshimov
I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.

Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Build Passthrough Pouring task; build MX Ink Tracing task; add neon halos and virtual liquid particles;

summary: Adaptive control and real-time feedback are crucial components of mixed reality rehabilitation systems to optimize user engagement and learning.
text: The system employs an adaptive controller that adjusts training parameters such as corridor width and tracing tunnel difficulty based on user performance. Feedback mechanisms are designed to fade over time, transitioning from knowledge of performance to knowledge of results as the user progresses. A projected dashboard provides real-time updates on metrics like on-path accuracy, tilt window, spills, RMS error, and SPARC, allowing for observation of adaptive difficulty and feedback fading. The system logs data at high frequencies (50 to 90 Hz) with rolling summaries to capture detailed performance information.

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.
III. OUTCOMES AND DEMONSTRATION
Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,
and fit to ARAT aligned tasks, with specific focus on clarity of halos, ticks and result cards (iii) Focus on the
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.

summary: Technical challenges in mixed reality development, such as anchor drift and noisy sensor data, require specific solutions to ensure reliable rehabilitation training.
text: Potential challenges include anchor drift, noisy tilt estimation, and inconsistent haptic support, which could impact the effectiveness of the training. Solutions to mitigate anchor drift involve relocalizing anchors at the start of each session. Noisy tilt estimation is addressed through low-pass filtering and debouncing events. The system aims for a high logging rate (50 to 90 Hz) with rolling summaries, but must manage challenges like overreactive difficulty oscillation and metric drift across sessions.

summary: The NeuroReach VR system utilizes specific tasks and multimodal feedback to target arm muscle activation for stroke recovery.
text: The system incorporates an ARAT-aligned pouring task and an MX Ink tracing task to train stroke patients. Multimodal feedback, including visual cues like neon halos and virtual liquid particles, and haptic feedback such as ticks, is integrated into the tasks. The goal is to improve selective muscle activation in the arms, which is essential for regaining functional movement after a stroke. A one-tap calibration UI is included to simplify the setup process for users.
